comments.commentBody:
While Bannon (and his cabal), Flynn and maybe Sessions maybe truly interested in ideology, I suspect that they are alone in that interest.

Quite frankly, if you were interested in big scale corruption, the Russia would be your best bet. They could easily turn Trump's failing empire into a success. And help others grow their fortunes.

Is this the motive? Who knows. Are all of them involved? Who knows.

I hope that Republican leaders will put their country first. The game is up. They won't get anything from Trump but grief. What is their endgame? Better to take their lumps now and go with Pence.

And I feel sorry for the millions who were conned once again by Trump. He is a grifter and always has been. I hope they have the courage to put their country first and defend our Constitution. Like the Republicans in Congress they will get nothing.

Actually Trump won because Anthony Weiner shared a laptop with Huma Abudeen.

Without this incredible vulnerability given by the Democratic campaign that a gop FBI director would exploit for unfair political gain, HRC would likely have actually won.

Trump's days of bullying the GOP congressional leaders with the cudgel of his reality-TV fan base are done. The Russia investigation is giving GOP congressional leaders tremendous leverage over Trump. If they refuse to stonewall public opinion and allow a full investigation -- which would include a demand to see Trump's tax returns -- Trump's presidency is doomed. Look for Trump to continue his public bluster and Twitter tantrums. But behind the scenes, Trump will comply with whatever the GOP congressional leaders want.

Who knows? Maybe after the GOP leadership has gotten what they want from Trump, they may throw him to wolves anyway. Trump has certainly tried to humiliate many of them in the past. It would be a fitting end to a reckless, amoral con man.

Thanks for explaining why the Russian ambassador was in Philly for the convention. Enquirering minds wanted to know.
Now, how the heck do we get out of this mess?
Waiting for the next election is clearly not an option.

Trump administration is in total meltdown mode. Carter Page on CNN was painful to watch even as his cynical lies were systematically exposed. He also connected many of these dots with what he said and did not say.

There they are, inside the circled wagons, with the evil king in the safest place. What else could the besiegers do but pick off the lesser villains one by one? Good tactic. In a game or a war.
Is this a real issue or a game? If it is a real issue, how come it's acting like a game? I hope it is a real issue because if it is a silly childish game, everyone is a silly child.
Perhaps it's time for the public to be shown some evidence of malfeasance.

There's a simple way to test the defense that Trump team interaction with Russian representatives was/is "normal": select another country important to the US such as China, Germany, the UK, or even Canada and document Trump team interactions with representatives of that country during and after the election.  That should prove to be an interesting comparison...
Any reasonable person can connect the dots here! Trump mentioned it several times in his book, winning what is matter and in this case he decided to betray the country to win
Also left out would be Nancy was not asked while under oath about this...Sessions was under oath when asked, and he lied.

Is it snowing in Moscow?

"Let's also reflect on why Trump won an election he should have lost in a landslide: Russia is not responsible for that."

Russian interference may well have been the reason Trump won the Electoral College. He lost the popular vote by three million.
What do the Russians have on Donald Trump?

"The libs are connecting the dots of these meetings while having already decided Trump is guilty for colluding with the Russians."

Might that have something to do with the president, while campaigning, openly inviting the Russians to hack his opponent's email.

Weren't tough dots to connect, Brian.

We used to separate liberal from conservative based either on the speed with with they welcomed change; then on whether they supported government efforts at dealing with wide-spread consequences of human conduct.  Now, it seems like liberal and conservative separate those who think government should support the individual in doing whatever they want to do, regardless of the effect on other people versus supporting the common good over what individuals want for themselves.  In all of these approaches, the work of Scott Walker in Wisconsin reminds us that the selfish, greedy and dishonorable approach to society still has its strong supporters like Walker.

Sigh.  I have been to many protests and I am not paid.  Nor are any of the other protesters---we just really don't agree with the GOP plan and don't like that the GOP is forcing the plan instead of compromising.  Take nominees selected to destroy the departments they are to head,  regulations and tax reductions on business that have seen the highest profits (as related to GDP) since 1947, the constant lies and ethical breaches, reduction of rights, unconstitutional laws, failure to base policy on fact....I could go on and on.  So, if you want to stop the protesting, start listening to what we are saying.  Compromise is possible but it takes both parties working together.  Mr. Walker's approach is the opposite of working together.

Walker's contorted, dishonest rhetoric illustrates that he cannot bargain in good faith.

"Americans were given a choice in November: Where do you want your dollar going?" Walker implies a mandate from voters, but the voters chose Hillary Clinton and the agenda she represented by a clear majority. Republicans have no mandate at all.

We, the majority, chose Hillary Clinton to expand health care and pay for it with higher taxes on billionaires. The clear majority of voters voted to strengthen public education, not privatization. And we place no trust in Putin whom Clinton rightly regards as a malevolent and corrupt dictator.

"But don’t let the left shape the debate," writes Walker, but the debate is way out of his control, just as the Trump administration is careening out of control. We will not be silenced, shut down, or sued into submission.

Conservatives always project their sins onto their victims, so it is no surprise that as Walker advocates measures to curtail free speech by intimidating dissent he poses as an innocent victim in need of protection. He is, in fact, the predator.

Richard, a first!
You pleasantly surprised me.
Maybe there is hope for America, after all.

(unless you define healthcare for "ALL" as having "access" which is unaffordable to many and makes "choice" laughable; age-based and inadequate, non-refundable tax credits that will only help those who work; caps and lifetime coverage limits; expensive state-run pools for preexisting conditions; policy cancellations when illness/disease strikes; ever-increasing high copays, deductibles and premiums; Health Savings Accounts which are tax shelters for the rich and are useless for the working poor; taxation as income of employer-paid health insurance; false promise of cost-controls based on competition across state lines which only work near state borders; loosely regulated Medicaid block grants to states which will decrease in dollars over time; etc.)

There is so much braggadocio in this piece of tripe that one cannot deal with it systematically. That is the current Republican strategy; through out so many false facts and half-truths that those who would like to respond are overwhelmed with the task.

Governor Walker talks of standing firmly against protesters but he come to our community and sequesters himself in friendly locales, with hand-picked audiences, blacks out the windows for fear of snipers, I suppose, surrounds himself with security and garners a spot on the evening news.

It is true that he has won a majority of the vote in the last tow elections (and in the recall) so he deserves to serve as Governor but, like the Trump people now, he forgets that nearly half the voters voted for his opponent in all of those elections. Still Republicans insist that they have "mandate" to impose their vision of America on the rest of us rather than recognizing - especially in the case of Trumps electoral college squeaker - that they have an obligation to work for all of us.

Walker demonstrated his lack of leadership in his run for the Presidency in 2015-16, embarrassing our state with his nonsensical comments in England and his total flop in the early primary debates. He is a tool of the Koch brothers as was demonstrated when he unknowingly was duped into granted a fake Donald Koch a twenty minute phone conversation (surreptitiously recorded) when he didn't have one minute to give to the state workers.

Earlier this week, the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel reported that Walker's refusal to raise any taxes for our roads will delay essential road projects, resulting in "more congestion, deteriorating road conditions and decades of delayed projects." And that is according to his own administration's findings. (http://www.jsonline.com/story/news/politics/2017/03/01/wisconsin-faces-t...

Decades of construction delays, decades of patching up failing roads, oh, and decades of borrowing money to cover the costs. You have to get the money from somewhere. Why no tax increases to raise the necessary money? Because Walker wants to run for President again in 2020 on a no-new-taxes platform.

Not only is this approach creating more potholes in our roads, it's blowing up our budget. Just to cover the temporary road fixes underway, the DOT is borrowing $144 million, and we will not make a principal payment on that loan for at least 2 years. And that's not the first time we borrowed money to pay for these roads.

I've long thought that the unusual circumstances that ushered in Walker and a Republican house and senate could be duplicated at the national level. Now that it has, I see the same for the country that we've experienced in Wisconsin: attacks on unions, voting rights, Planned Parenthood, environmental groups, the education system, and any progressive thought. Meanwhile, nobody is noticing the crumbling infrastructure and failing budget.

Scott Walker -- the tool who lived.

I've always wondered who Scooter was most paranoid of that he cost Wisconsin taxpayers thousands in security details:
Was it the nurses?
The school teachers?
Police?
Firemen?
After no mention of destroying unions in his campaign, he turned around and screwed these pillars of our communities, at the same time vilifying public service in general and teachers specifically in order to "divide and conquer" (his words to billionaire donor, Diane Hendricks) the citizenry he was elected to "govern."

He disclosed to a fake Koch Brother that he and his staff considered planting agitators among the peaceful protesters. The only violence reported at the Madison protests was a clip shown on Fox News with palm trees in the background (hint: palms don't grow here). Meanwhile, he disappeared from the public eye publicly stating he feared for his life, but we all know it's because he couldn't handle the pressure of facing his guilt.

And no it did NOT pay off. The school systems and infrastructure of the state are in tatters -- the former due to sabotage that intends to make privatization seem like the only solution and because all levels of education are seen as liberal strongholds that Republicans have been dying to undercut, and the latter due to neglect due to lack of funding. The economy stagnated as he didn't come close to delivering on his actual campaign promise of 250,000 new jobs.

What a tool!

It is so amazing to me how so many Republicans who espouse "conservative orthodoxy" can turn around and support Trump. I believe in conservatism as a viable and necessary force to counter the excesses of liberalism-just as liberalism is a necessary force for countering the excesses of conservatism. Trump has shown modern American conservatism to be a farce. As long as Trump declared that he was a Republican, he was "conservative." Not one Republican politician has unequivocally criticized President Trump. Rather, it is simply about closing ranks around the golden boy. The tragedy of the American two-party system is that naked partisanship and foolishness has been allowed to overtake integrity, objectivity and the very role Congress is supposed to play against the executive. Congress is supposed to check the executive, not let it run amok. That is an objective fact. Democrats must be more fervent in holding Trump's feet to the fire. Republicans, meanwhile, must step back from the spoils of their poisoned victory and assess Trump objectively and whether he is holding to conservative principles. I do not care whether a conservative or a liberal sits in the White House so long as congress ensures that the executive is working within its legal bounds. There is a good case to be made that Trump has overstepped those bounds. Therefore, both parties should come together, put aside their trivial partisan differences, and work to check the executive.

This op-ed writer misstates the intentions of the "founders" in regard to the powers of the states. Ultimate, individual state power was tried through the Continental Congress, which saw 13 former colonies that could not agree on anything, including national defense. That's why a second constitutional convention was called in Philadelphia in 1787: they knew they needed a national government, one that could supersede the squabbling of the individual states, which established 13 individual currencies and charged duties on "imported" goods crossing state lines. It was chaos. (There are many histories detailing these facts, one recent one being Carol Berkin's excellent book "The Bill of Rights").

States do not enjoy the flexibility of the national government in times of crisis or recession. Many are required to report balanced budgets, which means when the needs of citizens rise most intensely, the states have to slam the door in the faces of those most in need. The national economy, and federal budget, help to balance the various state and regional economies so that, to an important degree, no state is left dangling in the wind with extreme poverty and dire infrastructure needs unaddressed.

"Returning power to the states" is just another Republican argument for doing less. Scott Walker and many others lack the courage to stand up and say what they want, but what they really mean to do is cripple the federal power to override local, self centered stinginess. Don't be fooled.

I am annoyed that Walker is even published. The fact that he was once Senator from Massechuets, or that he once sported pink leather short shorts (I think he used to entertain women) does not mean that he has anything worthy to say.

He is simply mouthing the same old nonsense that Reagan mouthed 37 years ago. Hie positions are stupid, false and harmful. And most of all they don't reflect the changes that have taken place since 1980, when Reagan captured the Whitehouse.

He thinks regulations are excessive. After successive cutbacks since Reagan, the FDA has about 20 inspectors to examine all foods and drugs imported from China.

He thinks liberals have too much control and tax too much: The top one percent have a greater percentage of our national wealth than at any time since 1929.

He thinks that we are too soft on the poor and unfortunate. Nowadays, mentally ill people are frequently put in prisons; many prison services are contracted to private companies which abuse prisoners; and I have met AIDS patients who got food stamp allowances of 20 dollars for one month, etc.
People are bleeding. People are furious

And Scott Walker and his Reagan Republicanism are being buried as they should be.

Finally, how dare Walker claim that the voters, in 2016, signalled their support for the republicans. Hillary Clinton beat Donald Trump by about three milllion votes.

There are scads of stats indicating that so called "liberal" policies result in far better economic outcomes than trying to narrow and cutback the involvement of government. For one thing, the "tax and spend" for which liberals are accused constantly often means there is more investment in infrastructure, which assists with economic growth. (The wealthy would otherwise be hoarding their money or investing it elsewhere.) Furthermore, the right kind of investments can have a larger multiplier effect on the economy whereas cutting back, disinvestment, multiplies very little or nothing at all.

There are many signs (look at Kansas, Louisiana and others) that the tax cutting philosophy of Republicans, which is supposed to offer more jobs, does not work. The argument of Walker and his ilk seems to be derived, first and foremost, to be based on a desire to cut taxes on the richest constituents as a first case and then to find an excuse to believe that better results will come about for all. If those results don't materialize, doesn't matter. The purpose was the tax cut, not the imagined result.

As one of those 100000 plus persons who went perhaps loudly but peacefully to Madison to indicate that large numbers of Wisconsin residents wished to open a dialogue with Scott Walker over Act 10 and what it portended, I feel violated. In all of the weeks we attempted to be heard and have at least a delegation sit down with him for a civil conversation, he never responded except to make statements similar to this op-ed piece. He used a tunnel to come and go, indicated using thugs to make the protests appear violent, exaggerated the few really negative signs and threats. The recall was debated by several organisations and chosen as a risky and imperfect attempt to repeal Act 10 as Wisconsin law held no option to host a referendum such as was successful in Ohio later that year.
In the intervening years, Wisconsin has seen a rash of legislation that hurts ordinary citizens - from increasing aid to private schools to cutting DNR and environmental funding, to letting roads and bridges deteriorate to repressive voter regulations while packing the Supreme Court to adhere to Walker's agenda.
It certainly is not "standing tall" to refuse to have a real dialogue about issues and allow that perhaps every participant is right about something. What Scott Walker is promoting is a monarchy, not state government.
Just FYI - his Assembly leader Robin Vos (Republican) is currently spearheading a strong effort to raise the gas tax to improve roads and strongly resisting Walker.

What a narrative the Governor weaves here. The noble Republicans in their "fight" against "Washington". Sounding concerned about saving the taxpayers' money. He states that labor unions have too much control over the government. But, according to the excellent reporting of Charles P. Pierce in Esquire magazine, who has written extensively about this failed presidential candidate, he doesn't seem to mind being the pawn of his rich donors such as Home Depot co-founder Ken Langone, hedge-fund manager Paul Singer, Carl Icahn, Las Vegas casino magnate Sheldon Adelson, and billionaire home-improvement chain owner John Menard, according to files obtained under subpoena by investigators looking into campaign finance violations by the Walker campaign a number of years back, which was halted by the Wisconsin Supreme Court. The elected Wisconsin Supreme Court . Who terminated the investigation into Scott Walker after one of the right-wing judges, David Prosser, was re-elected with the help of allies of Scott Walker, who funneled undisclosed corporate funds of $3.5 million into radio and TV ads into the campaign. This preserved the conservative majority. Prosser then refused to recuse himself, and the investigation into Walker's campaign was stopped. Government in action, indeed.
Walker even solicited contributions from a lead-paint manufacturer, who then benefited from legislation blocking lawsuits from 170 affected children.
This is not how our founders envisioned our country.
